label: Letter 1 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, December 19, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, responding to the accusations she made in her last letter about him withholding information about their social activities on the island, that they had purchased a house, and that he was not writing to her “APO number.”

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, responding to the accusations she made in her last letter about him withholding information about their social activities on the island, that they had purchased a house, and that he was not writing to her “APO number.”

metadata.label: Access Note
metadata.value: All rights reserved. For more information and reuse requirements contact The College of Charleston Library, Charleston SC 29424.

metadata.label: Digitization Specifications
metadata.value: 300 dpi, 24-bit depth color, Epson Expression 10000XL, Archival Masters are tiffs.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
To Mrs Sidney J. Legendre,
O.S.S. Detachment,
A.P.O. No. 887
Postmaster, NEW YORK
From
Lt. S. Legendre USNR
PS BOX 166, Commandant
Navy No. 128
FL PO San Francisco
December 19, 1943
73
Dear Gertie,
Chrismas is rushing at us and I long so to be with you and spend
at least the day with you. To have a little tree and our present together
and maybe a fat spaniel to hug and play with. It would be heaven but then
one must not think of these things when they are unobtainable. I received
your letters 29,30, 32 today and loved them. You write such wonderful
letters , so full of news, and so interesting that I absolutely live for
them. I am so gald you are able to go out and play golf on the weekends
ocassionaly and that you have an opportunity to see doodles and breath a
little fresh air. It makes such a difference in your feelings and view
point on life. God only knows where stories about Morris and I start. We
do nothing, see no one, and as I told you in a letter before I did not even
know that I had seen Percy, Fraser, but thought that he might have been
the one that had talked to [me] about Ellen so much. Where he obtained the news
that Morris and I had bought a house is quite beyond me. We have not bought
so much as an out house, and are living in the same apartment, and will
probably continue to do so until the end of the war in 1949. We have not
been to see as house for the last three or four months and have no interest
in one. Next question in your letter is "what is my cable Address". I
will give it to you with the advise to please send me a letter telling what
was in the cable for I will never receive the latter. The address is Lt
S.J. Legendre, US Navy, Pearly Harbor. I did not know you had to send my 
number. You can well imagine my shames of receiving a cable with that
address. As I told you in a previous letter men out here only hear of the
death of their families when they receive the condolence letters as the
cables advising them of the fact never appear until months latter. I am
also amused at your saying why don't I write to your APO No. It seems to
me that I have been doing so for months. But then I must realize that it
takes a mo[n]th for my letter to reach you then another month for your reply
to reach me and a third mo[n]th for me to answer and tell you what I have to 
do about it. I guess when the war is over we will have to stay in our 
respective places for at least three mo[n]ths for our mail to cathc up with us
New interesting to have met those people from Charleston. Did they think as
we did that it was a dead place in a dreary climate with dull people and
wretched food. I am certain they must have been very glad to arrive in a
land where the war is the present one and not one that took place fifty 
years or so ago. I received a killing letter from Rose about her visit
down [t]here and in it you will note she said that which I xxx use to reiterate[,]
that the place was running better with just Walter and David and Rosa than
with all the servants, she had never seen it look lovilier. Four fifths
of the trouble with Medway was that we made it so dam difficult for ourselves
by always doing something that we never had time to enjoy it. Lats hope
someone else will get some pleasure out of it. Henry said he hear unofficialy
that we were to receive [illegible] for he damage done to our lake by
the canal. This sounds [illegible]
Sidney Legendre
